title: Adherence to HSE Regulations
category: 1. Ensure safe working conditions and care for our planet

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation: Company HSE rules are well-known and followed without any deviations.
items.evaluation: Request the most recent Region Safety Audit for a random area. Inspect the shop floor for the implementation of 3 random actions.
items.fully_applied: The Region Safety Audit was conducted in the past 12 months. For NG items there is an action plan and the contaniment is in place and validated by the HSE Region Manager.
items.partially_applied: The Region Safety Audit actions are delayed or not validated by the HSE Region Manager, although containment measures are in place.
items.not_applied:
No Region Safety Audits have been conducted in the past 12 months.

Containment measures have not been implemented.

No action plan has been defined.

items.evaluation: Monitor adherence to HSE corporate rules during the site audit. Randomly select a machine on the shop floor and verify how primary and secondary safety devices are inspected and documented.
items.fully_applied: All corporate HSE regulations are adhered to during the audit process.
items.partially_applied: The management team is capable of identifying deviations and responding immediately.
items.not_applied: The management team is unable to identify the deviation and has not taken immediate action.

items.evaluation: Observe and interview two operators (one from production and one from PC&L) to inquire about the HSE rules at the workstation.
items.fully_applied: Employees are familiar with and follow HSE workstation rules (SW, HSE instruction sheet, PPE). PPE is worn correctly.
items.partially_applied: Employees are unaware of the HSE rules and risks associated with the workstation.
items.not_applied: Employees are not adhering to HSE workstation rules (e.g., not wearing PPE or wearing incorrect PPE).

items.evaluation: Request 3 Safety Alerts  from the past 12 months and verify their proper assessment and application on the shop floor. Interview the management team about the Safety Alert Assessment process.
items.fully_applied: A tracking system is in place for Safety Alerts. These alerts are evaluated to identify any similar risks at the site, and a containment action plan is implemented accordingly.
items.partially_applied: The Safety Alert tracking system is in place, but actions are not implemented on time.
items.not_applied: The Safety Alert tracking system is in place, but the majority of actions are not implemented on time.

title: Risk: Preventive Measures
category: 1. Ensure safe working conditions and care for our planet

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation:
The daily hazard hunting process is in place and actively applied (including daily routines, indicators, etc.).









Risk assessments (including ergonomic assessments) and HSE core team processes are established.
items.evaluation:
Ask Team Leaders, Supervisors, and Managers about the hazard hunting process and the most recent hazard identified. 
Verify on the shop floor the actions taken for at least two closed hazards.
items.fully_applied:
Daily Hazard hunting activity done by Team Leader, Supervisors and Managers for all areas.
All hazard hunting are closed on time.
Containment applied when corrective actions still on-going
items.partially_applied: Daily hazard hunting activities are carried out by managers
items.not_applied: Daily hazard hunting activities are not conducted at the site level.

items.evaluation: Select two audits and ask the team members to explain the Safety audit content, its results, and the action plan. Interview Management Team members regarding their involvement in the Safety Core Teams' action plans.
items.fully_applied:
Safety Audit members conduct audits and can explain the process, the latest findings, and the action plan.  
Managers are responsible for leading the Safety action plan in their respective areas.
items.partially_applied: Site HSE is responsible for leading the site's action plan.
items.not_applied:
Safety audit members are unable to explain the process, recent audit findings, or the action plan.

The action plan is not being followed.

items.evaluation:
Request the risk assessment documents from the HSE responsible, inquire about the major changes, and verify that all HSE topics are considered. The risk assessment should cover all HSE aspects, including:

- Health (ergonomics, noise, chemical exposure, etc.)
- Safety (machinery, etc.)
- Fire risk
- Contractor activities, including onsite company operations (e.g., waste management)
items.fully_applied: Risk assessments cover all site activities (Production processes, PCL, Maintenance, etc) and are reviewed when relevant Safety Alerts are applicable, a safety incident occurs, after major changes or annually.
items.partially_applied: Risk assessments cover all site activities, although some site changes have not been included.
items.not_applied: The risk assessment does not cover all site activities, including new machines, processes, and workflows.

items.evaluation: Verify that an action plan is in place and managed by the site management team (select 3 actions randomly and inspect them on the shop floor) as part of the annual HSE management review.
items.fully_applied: An action plan is defined based on priority rules and managed at the site management team level.
items.partially_applied: The action plan aligns with the risk assessment findings, though some actions are not completed on time. Additionally, there has been no review of the risk assessment outputs during the management review.
items.not_applied: The action plan is not defined based on the identified priorities or it is not being followed

title: Organization Design
category: 2. Foster the development of competent, autonomous teams.

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation:
There is an active People Organization structure (Direct Labor (DL) & Indirect Labor (IDL)) developed by the Site Manager and their team, and validated by the Site Manager's N+1 (Sub Region Head).

When changes to the structure are planned, the management team follows this plan as part of their regular monthly cycle. This process is integrated with the S&OP meeting, ensuring clear awareness of the future organization, aligned with customer demand, and actions to ensure alignment.
items.evaluation:
Verify if the current structure outlined in the plan aligns with the actual situation on the shop floor across various teams.  

Review both the target and budgeted headcount for accuracy.  
Ask managers to present their people organization and the actions they are taking to meet their targets.

People Organization Ratios:
- Team Leader: Maximum of 8 people, including the Team Leader
- Supervisor: Maximum of 25 people
- Production Manager: Maximum of 200 people

These ratios may be relaxed if the following fundamentals are at least partially implemented on the shop floor in teams where the people organization standard is not being met: Team Leader Role, Supervisor Role, Mastery of Workstations, Standardized Work, and Driving Site Performance.
items.fully_applied: There is a clear organizational structure for the site that accurately reflects the current situation.
items.partially_applied:
An organization structure is in place for the current situation, but it is not reviewed on a monthly basis.

The people organization plan is not aligned with the Budget/forecast process.
items.not_applied:
No review of the people organization has been conducted or linked to the budget.

No target for people organization has been defined.

The people organization plan does not account for new project launches.

items.evaluation: Ask one management team about the analysis of the potential tasks to be transferred.
items.fully_applied: The management team has conducted an analysis of the potential tasks to be transferred, with a defined process in place.
items.not_applied: The management team has not conducted an analysis of the potential tasks to be transferred.

title: Hiring Process
category: 2. Foster the development of competent, autonomous teams.

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation:
For every open employee position, a job description is provided, and validation is required to fill the role.

A target deadline is established for closing each recruitment process.

Open shopfloor labor positions are communicated internally (via communication boards, intranet, etc.), unless they are confidential or part of a predefined career move.

All Direct Labor candidates (including temporary) are evaluated according to the site's defined procedure.

When an external agency is used for recruitment, the site ensures that the agency adheres to the minimum hiring requirements.
items.evaluation:
For one Salary Exempt data from the system and one Hourly Indirect recruitment (within the last 12 months or most recent recruitment):
- Request the job description and interview forms.
- Ensure that the Indirect Labor vacancies (both internal and external) from the past 12 months were posted internally (e.g., in the system, on the communication board, or through internal job bids).
items.fully_applied: A job description (including leadership competencies, minimum qualifications, and ideal candidate profile) is available for each Indirect Labor vacancy.
items.partially_applied: The Job Description is missing one or more components: description, competencies, minimum qualifications, or experience.
items.not_applied: A job description/job profile has not been defined.

items.evaluation: Review validation process for Indirect Labor and Direct Labor   requests.
items.fully_applied: Indirect Labor candidates are assessed according to the ideal candidate profile using an Interview Evaluation Form, with evaluations compared using a matrix.
items.partially_applied: Candidate evaluations are conducted using an Interview Evaluation Form, but the assessments are not compared to the ideal candidate profile.
items.not_applied: Indirect Labor recruitment has been conducted without any evaluation (typically using an evaluation form).

items.evaluation:
For Direct Labor, verify the test and evaluation criteria. 

If no recruitment has occurred in the last 12 months or previous year, the question is not applicable.
items.fully_applied: For Direct Labor, the assessment of recruited candidates aligns with the minimum criteria defined in the site procedure.
items.partially_applied:
One or more recruitment assessments are missing.

One or more Direct Labor (DL) candidates were assessed below the minimum criteria and were still recruited."
items.not_applied:
The Direct Labor recruitment process has not been followed:

- No recruitment assessment has been performed.
- Minimum criteria have not been defined or adhered to."

title: New Hire Orientation
category: 2. Foster the development of competent, autonomous teams.

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation:
An onboarding plan for all newly hired Indirect Labor (IDL) employees is established between the HR Manager and Hiring Manager. This plan includes the ASTEMO induction, site induction, and position-specific induction.

For internal transfers, only a position-related induction plan, which includes relevant training, is provided.

MOOCs: Massive Open Online Courses (Digital Training)
items.evaluation:
Interview two Indirect Labor (IDL) employees recruited within the past 12 months or during the most recent recruitment to assess their onboarding experience:
- Evaluate their understanding of the process
- Record the information in the relevant system
- Ensure the key actions align with Astemo Procedures
- Verify if any position- or function-specific tasks were addressed

Ask the Indirect Labor (IDL) employees about any areas not fully covered during the induction and what steps were taken to address their concerns.
items.fully_applied:
All newly hired Indirect Labor (IDL) employees and internal mobilities have an onboarding plan.



For internal transfers within or between sites, a handover period is established and carried out.
items.partially_applied:
An onboarding process exists for each Indirect Labor (IDL) employee, including internal mobilities, but it is not completed within 6 months. More than three items are either not done or lack scheduled dates (whether the onboarding is in progress or finished).

No training specific to the new position is provided (only ASTEMO and site presentations), even when required, including for internal mobilities.

Shopfloor experience has not been conducted.

Mandatory MOOCs have not been completed.
items.not_applied:
Indirect Labor (IDL) employees were hired without an onboarding process.

There is no final review with HR and N+1.

No handover has been defined or carried out for planned internal transfers within or between sites.

Mandatory MOOCs have not been identified in the planning.

items.expectation: All Direct Labor (DL) employees, including temporary workers, receive a specific induction plan starting on their first day.
items.evaluation:
Request the documented induction and training process for new Direct Labor (DL) employees.

Additionally, ask a recent newcomer about their induction experience.
items.fully_applied:
All Direct Labor (DL) employees, including temporary staff, undergo induction on their first day or before starting, covering the following:
- Site safety requirements
- Safety & Regulatory (if applicable)

Within the first week, the induction also includes:
- HR administrative matters
- Site operations
- Key products and customers
- Basic overview of OES
items.partially_applied: One of the activities listed was not covered during the first week but has been rescheduled.
items.not_applied: One of the activities listed for the first day or before is not covered.

title: Training Plan
category: 2. Foster the development of competent, autonomous teams.

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation:
A training plan is in place for the defined population, focusing on internal topics, and is validated by the Site and HR Director. The plan includes training hours, budgeted costs, and key training priorities.

Inputs include:
- Specific training needs of managers, new projects, new technologies, IDPs, potential career progression, and more.

The training plan is finalized by the end of March, in alignment with the talent review process, addressing training needs and hours per person. It is periodically reviewed (e.g., monthly) for effectiveness, with the management team overseeing progress (under the Director's responsibility and supported by HR), including corrective actions for any delays.

Completion of mandatory e-learning courses (such as operations, OES Basics, etc.) is required.

A system for evaluating training effectiveness is in place to improve Site KPIs.
items.evaluation:
Request a manager to explain the process for creating the training plan and provide an update on the status of their own training plan.

Ask a supervisor about their role in the training plan.
items.fully_applied: Each manager, including supervisors, develops a training plan for Indirect Labor (IDL) and Direct Labor (DL) based on the training priorities established at the site. These priorities may stem from a combination of the Individual Development Plan (IDP), Annual Performance Appraisal, Site Improvement Plan (SIP), budget, and other factors.
items.partially_applied:
The supervisor is unable to demonstrate their involvement in creating the training plan.

There are no defined training priorities at the site level.
items.not_applied:
There is no training plan available at the site level.

The training plan is created solely by HR, with no involvement from the Department Manager.

The training plan includes only Indirect Labor (IDL) and does not cover Direct Labor (DL).

items.evaluation:
Review the training guidelines and priorities set for the site.

Examine the training plan tool/database (both planned and completed).
items.fully_applied: The training plan for both IDL and DL is regularly reviewed by the management team (responsible manager, HR, and support function), with comments included if any delays occur.
items.partially_applied:
The training plan is not reviewed quarterly.

Less than 60% of the training plan events have been completed year-to-date.

Department managers are unable to explain the current status of their training plans.

There are no comments provided for delayed training actions.
items.not_applied:
The training plan is not reviewed by the management team.

Less than 40% of the planned training events have been completed (either as planned or rescheduled).

items.evaluation: Review the OES training planning.
items.fully_applied: An OES training plan is established at a minimum for managers and supervisors.
items.partially_applied: An OES training plan is defined at a minimum for managers but does not include supervisors.
items.not_applied: The training plan does not provide a comprehensive view of the OES system (e.g., EE, HSE, Lean, Pull system, 8 Quality Control Points, etc.).

title: Team Leader Role
category: 2. Foster the development of competent, autonomous teams.

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation: The Team Leader addresses variations that arise on the production line (such as non-conformities, missing or defective materials, rework, equipment or process failures, apprentices, etc.) to prevent them from impacting production performance. Production operators focus on adhering to Standardized Work and do not handle variability directly.
items.evaluation:
Verify if Team Leaders are identified on the line and if their Leader Standard Work (LSW) includes individual training guides.

Randomly check line indicators and targets across different lines.

Ensure that Team Leader Standard Work (LSW) documents are living documents, updated with content reflecting current operational issues or improvement priorities, including weekly time spent off the line.

Observe during the assessment how variations (such as reworks, material shortages, equipment failures, etc.) are managed on the line, and how operators handle variations not covered by Standardized Work.

Check for examples of past actions or focus areas implemented based on the development guide.
items.fully_applied: The Team Leader has daily tasks defined, tailored to each individual's development (e.g., their Training Guide/actions) and the needs of the team.
items.partially_applied:
The Team Leader Standard Work (LSW) is not clearly aligned with their Individual Development Guide or the line performance requirements. 
The routine content is standardized for all Team Leaders.
items.not_applied: There is no Team Leader Standard Work (LSW) available.

items.evaluation: Conduct interviews with operators and attend their Daily Accountability Meeting.
items.fully_applied: The daily accountability meeting is led by the Team Leader using a board. During the meeting, the team reviews line performance indicators, shares updates or issues from previous shifts, and takes necessary actions (deciding or communicating the plan for the day).
items.partially_applied:
The team is not engaged during the daily accountability meeting.

Line performance indicators and daily actions are not reviewed during the meeting.

No general information is shared, if applicable.
items.not_applied:
There is no use of the Performance Indicator Board.

No daily accountability meeting is held during the shift.

Some team members do not attend the daily accountability meeting.

title: Supervisor Role
category: 2. Foster the development of competent, autonomous teams.

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation:
The Supervisor has a Leader Standard Work (LSW) in place to drive improvement actions, such as ensuring adherence to standards, advancing KPIs, and developing competencies. Examples include:

- Execution of Team Leader Standard Work (LSW)
- 5S
- HSE (EPI, 1st Piece HSE, etc.)

items.evaluation:
Verify if Supervisors are assigned to specific lines and if their routines are aligned with their development guides and actions.

Ensure that Supervisor routines, dashboards, and scorecards are living documents, updated with content reflecting current operational issues or improvement priorities.

Confirm that the key KPIs on their dashboards/scorecards are linked to annual objectives.
items.fully_applied: The Supervisor has a Leader Standard Work (LSW) that is tailored to support their role development (e.g., individual development guide).
items.partially_applied: The Supervisor's Leader Standard Work (LSW) is not clearly aligned with their Individual Development Guide or specific area needs (e.g., individual development guide, development actions).
items.not_applied: The Supervisor's Leader Standard Work (LSW) is either unavailable, not used, or outdated.

title: Talent Succession and Career Development
category: 2. Foster the development of competent, autonomous teams.

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation:
The site has implemented the Individual Development Plan (IDP) process and, in collaboration with the Region, has identified who should have an IDP.

The Career Interview process is in place at the site level, based on requests from the GPM process (Talent Management) and/or led by the Site HR Manager.
items.evaluation: Review the previous year's Annual Performance Management Process (e.g., GPM), the requests for Career interviews, Ready for Career Development (RCD) assessments and Salary Exempt seniority in the position held for more than 5 years.
items.fully_applied: The site is utilizing the Career Interview process.
items.partially_applied: Less than 75% of requests for Career Interviews (stemming from annual appraisals, RCDs, or roles held for over 5 years) were completed in the previous year.
items.not_applied: Less than 50% of requests for Career Interviews (from annual appraisals, RCDs, or roles held for over 5 years) were completed in the previous year.

items.evaluation: Evaluate the Career Development process at the site by reviewing at least two Career discussions and IDPs.
items.fully_applied: The site has implemented the IDP process, with identified actions, for over 75% of all potential candidates.
items.partially_applied: Between 25% and 75% of all potential candidates have an IDP, or the actions outlined in the IDP are not being followed.
items.not_applied: Less than 25% of potential talent (Salary Exempt) have an IDP.

items.evaluation: Select one IDP managed by the site and review it (can be for any position).
items.fully_applied: When an Indirect Hourly or non-Salary Exempt employee has been identified with the potential for a larger role, the Career Interview process was followed according to the site’s defined procedure.
items.partially_applied: No Hourly Indirect employees have been identified for a career discussion, or planned/requested career interviews have not been completed for this group.
items.not_applied:
No non-Salary Exempt employees have been identified for internal mobility or promoted in the past year (e.g., from Operator to Team Leader).

For Hourly Indirect employees, less than 25% of requested career discussions have been planned or completed, or there is a discrepancy between actual and planned outcomes from previous years.

items.expectation: There is a clear succession plan in place for key positions in the short and mid-term, taking turnover into consideration.
items.evaluation:
Review the documentation used for the People/Talent review process for all key positions (Salary Exempt, Indirect Hourly, Direct Labor (DL)) on an annual basis.

Ask management members to explain the people review process.
items.fully_applied:
All identified key positions have a short- or mid-term backup or successor (either internally or externally, such as from the region, corporate, or other sites).

At least 70% of the site-defined key positions must have a short-term backup.
items.partially_applied:
Less than 80% of N-1 key positions have a backup/successor (short or mid-term), or there is no action plan in place to cover the position.

The succession plan is not reviewed annually.

Only N-1 positions are included in key positions.
items.not_applied: Less than 50% of N-1 key positions have a backup or successor (short or mid-term), and there is no action plan in place to cover these roles.

The official nomination by the Site Head for Site launch representatives includes:
- Launch Manager or equivalent
- Site Launch Team (at a minimum, the Production Manager, Supervisor, Logistics, Quality, Engineering, Maintenance, OES, and HSE) at the start of the Design Phase.

Is SASG being used?

Follow the Non-SASG process
Establish the Launch team organization.

items.partially_applied: A Launch Area (physical or digital) is in place, with 80% of the routines being followed.

Single List of Issues/Management:

items.not_applied: The Launch Manager (or equivalent) does not follow the Site Single List of Issues, and critical issues are not escalated to Program Management/Site.

items.expectation:

- KPIs are tracked in Hiper.
items.evaluation:

- Is there an open issues list being tracked with dates, safety, regulatory requirements, and responsible members?

- Does the Launch team have a launch schedule that is regularly reviewed?
items.fully_applied: Relevant KPIs are defined by production line/process according to Program recommendations (including definition, target, current status, and actions).
items.partially_applied: KPIs are defined according to the Program, but not at the production line/process level (definition, target, current status).
items.not_applied: KPIs are either missing or partially defined, or targets or current status not provided.

title: Launch Staffing & Training
category: 2. Foster the development of competent, autonomous teams.

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation:
For Direct Labor (DL) & Indirect Labor (IDL):
The hiring and staffing plan is reviewed periodically based on the program/project phase, with a Convergence Plan in place in case of discrepancies.
The hiring and training plan for each line and shift is defined according to program/project needs, with minimum requirements including:

Customer milestones (Run@Rate, ramp-up, etc.)
ASTEMO milestones (PT/MPT/EMPT/SOP)
Industrial planning
Training duration requirements
Number of operators per process (for direct labor)
Critical and Safety & Regulation stations

Final inspection

Plan vs. actual performance

items.evaluation:
Request the Hiring and Training Plan for Direct Labor and Supervisors, as outlined in the Design Phase, from the Launch Manager (or equivalent) and Production Manager.

Interview the Production Manager to obtain the Training Plan for Direct Labor and Supervisors, as well as the Process and Ramp-Up Plan for new programs.

Inquire with the Production Manager about the follow-up actions required during the Industrialization Phase.
items.fully_applied: The hiring and training plan for Supervisors and Direct Labor (DL) includes defining the skill levels for Direct Labor (plan vs. actual) based on the inputs, with regular follow-up. In case of any deviations, a convergence plan is in place.
items.partially_applied: The hiring and training plan for Supervisors and Direct Labor is established (plan vs. actual) and monitored, but there is no convergence plan for addressing deviations.
items.not_applied: The hiring and training plan is either undefined or not monitored.

items.evaluation:
Interview the Team Leader to:

Verify if Direct Labor (DL) are adequately trained according to the approved Training Plan.

Assess the implementation of Standard Work for both manual and automated processes.

Review the training provided to operators/technicians based on the Work Instructions for automated processes.
items.fully_applied: The target and attainment of skill levels align with the training plan and Standardized Work.
items.partially_applied: The actual skill level does not align with the current status of the training plan.
items.not_applied: Standardized Work is undefined, or there is no evidence of the skill level(s).

Identify an operator or Direct Labor (DL) based on the Training Plan and Skill Matrix.
Request the Team Leader to conduct a Standardized Work audit with the selected operator.
The audit should focus on adherence to process steps, Self-Inspection procedures, and cycle time.
items.fully_applied: The operator is capable of performing Standardized Work based on the reported skill level (I, L, or U).
items.partially_applied: The operator can perform Standardized Work according to the reported skill level (I, L, or U), with minor discrepancies identified.
items.not_applied: The operator is unable to perform Standardized Work according to the reported skill level (I, L, or U), with significant discrepancies identified.

title: Standardized Work (SW)
category: 3. Implement standardized work practices.

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation:
Standard Work Instructions are available for all line configurations, outlining the best way to perform tasks. In PC&L, this includes activities such as tugger carts, kitting, and sequencing. For other logistics activities (e.g., forklift, walterspider), Work Instructions focusing on key tasks may be acceptable.

Standardized Work activities cover all areas: Quality, Safety, Ergonomics, Production, and PC&L.

Operators consistently follow Standard Work (the same way, each cycle).

Standard Work documents are created by supervisors and/or Team Leaders with input from engineering and quality, based on authorized methods. These documents are readily accessible at the line side for Team Members to reference and review.

Team Leaders (Production/PC&L) regularly audit operators to assess their ability to follow Standard Work. This review helps reduce abnormalities, variability, and waste (including work content). Supervisors conduct at least two Standard Work audits per week: one to observe another Team Leader and one where the Supervisor actively participates in a Standard Work audit for coaching purposes.
items.evaluation:

items.partially_applied: The withdrawal period does not align with the production line's operating hours.
items.not_applied: Parts are gathered without clear instructions regarding what to withdraw, when, the quantity, or the associated product code or inventory purpose.

category: 9. Operate with only the necessary resources

items.expectation: Expectation

items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation:
For machine-driven lines (where the machine is the bottleneck), the target is aligned with the Machine Cycle Time (MCT).

For manpower-driven lines (where the operator is the bottleneck), the target is aligned with the Standard Cycle Time.

Actual production is updated in real-time (at least every hour).

Triggers for reaction are clearly defined.

Reaction rules are defined and consistently applied.
















Operators are empowered to apply the defined reaction rules (e.g., stop, call wait, HSE risk, shortage of components, unknown issues, abnormalities) and request support from the Team Leader.
items.evaluation:
Challenge the target for a full hour without any planned events (such as changeovers or planned stoppages).

Verify the actual performance hour by hour to ensure the data is accurate.

Ask what the triggers are for reacting to performance deviations.
items.fully_applied:
Handwritten or digital solution:  
- The hour-by-hour chart is well utilized:  
  - It is filled for all previous hours with green/red color indicating performance.  
  - The target is clearly defined.  
  - Comments are added when production falls below the target.
items.partially_applied:
There is no use of green/red color on the hour-by-hour chart.  

If the output is not updated in real-time, it is not acceptable.  

Some comments are missing when deviations occur.
items.not_applied:
No target is defined.  

Some hours are not filled in with actual results.  

Comments are systematically missing when deviations occur.

items.evaluation:
For a machine-driven line:  
- Compare the target with the Machine Cycle Time (MCT) and Standard Cycle Time (ST).  
- Confirm that actions are taken based on the HR per hour results.
items.fully_applied:
For a machine-driven line:  
The real/actual Machine Cycle Time is aligned with the parts board target.
items.partially_applied:
For the machine-driven line:  
- The target on the parts board is for the wrong part number.  
- There is a mismatch (±) between the real/actual Machine Cycle Time and the parts board target, or the Standard Time Efficiency (ST Eff'y) is higher than 110%.
items.not_applied:
For the machine-driven line:  
- There is a mismatch (±) between the real/actual Machine Cycle Time and the parts board target, or the Standard Time (ST) / Efficiency (Eff'y) time is higher than 120%.

items.evaluation:
For a manpower-driven line:

- Compare the target with the real Cycle Time.
- To assess Real Cycle Time: consider the speed of the line in a continuous flow system or the operator bottleneck station time (using Cycle Time Diagram/Standardized Work).
- Verify if the parts board’s actual column is filled in (at least hourly) with accurate data.
- Ask what the triggers are for reacting to performance deviations.

It is acceptable if the parts board is not updated during the recovery period, as long as comments are present (e.g., "Team Leader on line to recover").
items.fully_applied:
For a manpower-driven line:

The real Cycle Time is aligned with the target on the display board and at the Operator Bottleneck Station.

This applies only to daily produced parts on dedicated lines.
items.partially_applied:
For the manpower-driven line:  
- There is a mismatch (±) between the target and the real Cycle Time, with the Standard Time Efficiency (ST Eff'y) being higher than 10%.
items.not_applied:
For the manpower-driven line:  
- There is a mismatch (±) between the target and the real Cycle Time, and/or the Standard Time Efficiency (ST eff'y) is higher than 20%.

items.evaluation:
Go to the line and simulate an Andon situation, then wait for the Team Leader's arrival.  

This is applicable for representative capacity and assembly lines that operate with opening times longer than one shift and have a large amount of direct labor.  

It is not applicable to service part lines.
items.fully_applied: In the event of a line issue or potential problem (such as stoppage, quality concerns, or an almost empty flow rack), an Andon system is in place to alert the Team Leader. The Team Leader responds to Andon system calls and is aware of which area requires support.
items.partially_applied: The system exists, but the Team Leader is not reacting, and/or the Team Leader does not know where to provide support.
items.not_applied: There is no Andon system for more than 50% of the representative capacity and assembly lines.

Assess the actions defined during the meetings to improve performance, ensuring that specific action plans are in place. Additionally, check if any adjustments are being made to Supervisor/Team Leader routines as part of the improvement process.

In the event of deviations or negative trends in KPIs:

items.expectation:

Problem Solving is used not only as a reaction to customer or internal issues but also as a preventive measure to avoid future issues. The 8D Problem-Solving process aims to:

- Ensure immediate customer protection.
- Identify root causes related to non-detection and occurrence of issues.
- Identify systemic causes for both occurrence and non-detection.
- Implement corrective actions to eliminate root causes.
- Track the effectiveness of the corrective actions.
- Update documentation and share Lessons Learned across relevant teams.
items.evaluation: Ask the Quality Manager for the most recent customer complaints from the past six months, or longer if available. If no formal complaints exist, inquire about any unofficial complaints or internal issues, particularly those related to frequent problem areas such as Final Inspection or Scrap.

items.partially_applied:

D3 Containment and inventory control actions are implemented and effective, but not within 24 hours for official/unofficial customer claims.
items.not_applied: An 8D is missing for at least one official customer claim. No 8D report is available.

items.evaluation:
Ask the Quality Manager for a closed 8D report (from the past 6 months), along with any customer claims, unofficial complaints, or internal issues (such as Scrap, etc.).
- Review the related 8D, ensuring deadlines for D3, D6, and D8 steps align with the target.
-Verify the problem description.
- Evaluate containment actions (D3 Clean point) and their effectiveness.
- Assess D4 and D5 steps according to the methodology.
- Confirm that D6 actions were completed on time.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of corrective actions in D7.
- Ensure D8 includes updates to documents and lessons learned.
items.fully_applied:
In 8D - D1, the internal view translates the "customer" symptom into a technical perspective, thereby narrowing the scope.

D3 is completed within 24 hours of receiving the incident for both official and unofficial claims.

Containment and inventory control actions are implemented and effective, with a defined clean point.
items.not_applied: D3 shows insufficient containment or inventory control for official customer claims. NO GOOD parts were found after the clean point.

title: Voice of the Customer
category: 11. Transform towards Excellence (Kaizen and Breakthrough)

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation:
Understand the true customer voice (feedback) and level of intimacy, as well as the improvement projects in place.

Site leadership should conduct regular reviews of customer relationships, focusing on intimacy, customer feedback, and the customer voice.

The site leadership team must proactively engage with customers on a consistent basis, regardless of whether any issues are present.

A Voice of Customer (VOC) scorecard must be established for all ASTEMO customers, visible at the site, and include relevant information regarding ASTEMO/Site performance and customer perception.

Ensure alignment with the customer on key areas, including:

The current status of the business
Customer expectations (e.g., quality, logistics, program launches)
Internal metrics (input KPIs) that are critical to customer satisfaction
Adapt and align with evolving customer conditions, such as organizational changes or new relationships.
items.evaluation:
Ask the Quality Manager for the current status of the scorecard and any actions being taken, if needed.

Check the customer portal for the latest results, complaints, escalation status, etc., and compare them with the scorecard.

Request to see any action plans in place to address issues related to key priorities and to drive progress on KPIs.
items.fully_applied: The VOC scorecard is aligned with the customer portal. Monthly follow-ups are conducted for the Voice of Customer (VOC) scorecard, with action plans implemented in case of any deviations.
items.partially_applied: The VOC scorecard is available, but no actions have been taken in response to deviations.
items.not_applied: The Voice of Customer (VOC) scorecard is either not available or not aligned with the customer portal status.

items.expectation:
The site conducts a risk assessment each semester, including a mitigation plan for red criteria (level 2).

The assessment is reviewed quarterly to account for potential changes in program allocation, mobility of the Ops Director or Site Manager, or any significant issues affecting site performance (e.g., customer escalations).

The site risk assessment is aligned with the program risk assessment.
items.evaluation:
Request the two most recent Site Risk Assessments from the Site Head and verify if they address the following areas:
- Site maturity
- People stability
- Program launches
- Customer voice
- Supplier readiness
items.fully_applied: The Site Risk Assessment is conducted quarterly in accordance with the standard by the Site Head and Sub-Region Head.
items.partially_applied: The Site Risk Assessment is conducted each semester, following the standard, by the Site Head and Sub-Region Head.
items.not_applied: The Site Risk Assessment is not conducted each semester.

items.evaluation: Review the mitigation plan for level 2 criteria to ensure it is properly addressed.
items.fully_applied: The mitigation plan is being executed for level 2 criteria.
items.partially_applied: A mitigation plan exists and is being executed for at least 80% of level 2 criteria.
items.not_applied: The mitigation plan has not been defined for Level 2 criteria.

items.evaluation: Request the Program Risk Assessment completed by the Program Director and Site Manager.
items.fully_applied: Program and Site Risk Assessments should be aligned for common criteria. If discrepancies arise, the Site Head must provide a justification.

title: Employee Engagement  and Communication Plan
category: 11. Transform towards Excellence (Kaizen and Breakthrough)

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation:
Managers are responsible for understanding, analyzing, planning, and taking actions to maintain motivation and engagement of their employees, while assessing the effectiveness of these actions. This includes:

- Ensuring employees understand their role, from company and customer requirements to their involvement in the continuous improvement process.

- Managing the onsite communication process across different daily accountability meetings.

- Developing a plan to engage employees, which may include communication structures, newsletters, recognition of improvement ideas, Employee of the Month, etc. Each site should tailor this plan to its specific needs.

- A primary goal is to ensure workforce stability, with planning reflecting the actual team stability (turnover and absenteeism) situation at the site.
items.evaluation:
Review the site’s motivation, engagement, and communication plan (both planned and executed).

Examine the results of the indicators defined by the site.

Ask a supervisor about their active contributions to supporting the plan.

Ask the Production Manager and PC&L Manager what actions they are taking to support this plan, and the indicator selected to track employee engagement.
items.fully_applied:
The site has implemented various Employee Motivation and Engagement activities over the past year, tailored to their needs, including local initiatives (e.g., recognition systems, employee surveys, Employee of the Month, etc.).

Management selects relevant indicators to monitor site engagement, based on an analysis of areas that require improvement.
items.partially_applied:
A plan is in place to support engagement, but up to 30% of the actions have not been completed.

Employee motivation and engagement activities do not involve all organizational levels of the site (e.g., supervisors or team leaders).

The indicator(s) chosen by management to track engagement are not on target (within +/-10%).
items.not_applied:
There is no plan in place, or more than 30% of the planned actions have not been completed.

The Site Manager has not conducted a semester meeting (Town Hall/General Assembly).

No indicators have been selected to measure engagement.

items.evaluation: Ask the Site Head what actions they are actively taking to support the plan.
items.fully_applied: A daily communication process is in place, including daily accountability meetings, monthly department reviews, and semester-wide site communication (such as General Assembly or Town Hall meetings).
items.partially_applied: Some departments are not conducting the monthly reviews.

items.evaluation:
"Check the percentage of Indirect Labor (IDL) and Direct Labor (DL) turnover and resignations compared to the target on the HR KPI Dashboard. 

KPI = Turnover Resignation (registered)."
items.fully_applied: The management team monitors team stability and takes action if the trends or actual figures exceed their target.
items.partially_applied: Actions are in place to ensure stability if the target is at risk or has been exceeded.
items.not_applied: There is no action or response when the stability target is exceeded.

title: Energy & CO2 reduction
category: 11. Transform towards Excellence (Kaizen and Breakthrough)

items.expectation: Expectation
items.evaluation: How to evaluate
items.fully_applied: Fully applied
items.partially_applied: Partially applied
items.not_applied: Not applied

items.expectation: CO2 neutrality is a strategic objective (2030 goal), and the site must align its internal management with this strategic priority.
items.evaluation:
The CO2 champion must be identified through a nomination letter or by their position within the site’s organizational chart.

Ask the Site Manager and the CO2 champion to explain the site’s initiatives for CO2 reduction.

Request the latest site report on the Global Monozukuri Carbon Neutral plans.

Review the site’s current plan to achieve carbon goals by 2030.
items.fully_applied:
Transformation Governance:

- An Energy & CO2 champion is appointed to coordinate the transformation efforts.

- A Pareto analysis is conducted to identify the main factors influencing energy consumption and is reviewed every 6 months.

- The KPIs from the Pareto analysis are monitored at least on a weekly basis.

- The Carbon Neutral Initiatives plan was updated within the last 12 months.
items.partially_applied:
Transformation Governance:

- An Energy & CO2 champion is appointed to oversee the transformation efforts.

- While a Pareto analysis is not defined, the main energy and CO2 KPIs have been identified.

- KPIs are reviewed at least on a monthly basis.

- The Carbon Initiatives plan is not visibly available for the past year, but it is no older than 24 months.
items.not_applied:
Transformation Governance:

- No CO2 champion has been appointed to coordinate the transformation.

Or

- No action plan is available.

items.expectation:
Management actions and technical measures are implemented to adjust machine and utility consumption to the necessary levels.

Instructions and visual management tools are provided to explain how and when to adjust consumption.
items.evaluation:
Energy-intensive machines and utilities are identified based on a Pareto analysis.

Verify if visual identification is in place for energy-intensive machines and utilities.

Check during breaks or when shifts are not running to ensure intensive machines are turned off and utility usage is adjusted accordingly.

Instructions for starting and stopping machines specify what to start/stop, how to do so, and when to start/stop (e.g., during breaks, changeovers, end of shifts, weekends, holidays).
items.fully_applied:
Standard Work, Planning & Execution

- Energy-intensive machines and utilities are identified, with the top 10 clearly flagged on the shop floor.

- Machines and utilities are turned off (or adjusted as per instructions) when there is no production.

- Instructions or documentation are available for starting and stopping the site’s most energy-intensive machines (at least the top 10).

- The Manufacturing Engineering team can explain how the energy consumption of the top 10 most energy-intensive machines and main utilities (e.g., compressors, lights, chilled water, hot water) is adjusted according to activity. This explanation is supported by documented analysis.
items.partially_applied:
Standard Work, Planning & Execution

The top 10 energy-intensive production machines are turned off (or adjusted as per instructions) when there is no production.
items.not_applied:
Standard Work, Planning & Execution

The top 10 energy-intensive machines are not turned off when there is no production, and no instructions are available.
